analytic.title: Dynamic Output Feedback Control of Switched Linear Systems

div.p: This paper is devoted to stability analysis and control design of switched linear systems in both continuous and discrete-time domains. A particular class of matrix inequalities, the so-called Lyapunov-Metzler inequalities, provides conditions for open-loop stability analysis and closed-loop switching control using state and output feedback. Switched linear systems are analyzed in a general framework by introducing a quadratic in the state cost determined from a series of impulse perturbations. Lower bounds on the cost associated with the optimal switching control strategy are derived from the determination of a feasible solution to the Hamilton-Jacobi-Bellman inequality. An upper bound on the optimal cost associated with a closed-loop stabilizing switching strategy is provided as well. The solution of the output feedback problem is based on the construction of a full-order linear switched filter whose state variable is used by the mechanism for the determination of the switching rule. Throughout, the theoretical results are illustrated by means of academic examples. A realistic practical application related to the optimal control of semiactive suspensions in road vehicles is reported.

This paper is devoted to the analysis and control design of switched linear systems in both, continuous-and discrete-time settings.

Stability analysis of continuous-time switched linear systems has been addressed by many authors [4], [12], [13], [15], and [23]. In reference [12], the interested reader can find an interesting discussion on a collection of results on uniform stability of switched systems. However, very little attention has been devoted to the design of stabilizing output feedback control laws [9]. The reader is requested to see [8], [16], and [17] for a rather complete review on stability of continuous-time switched linear systems, where special attention is given to the case of switching between two linear systems. The same reference also provides a discussion on hybrid feedback control based on output measurements, which, in our opinion, cannot be directly generalized to cope with the problem to be stated afterwards. The situation is even poorer in discrete time, where only a few works have appeared for the stabilization problem, see, e.g., [6], [7], [22], and [24]. In this paper, the stability conditions for continuous-and discrete-time linear switched systems, provided, respectively, in [10] and [11], are used. They are expressed through the so-called Lyapunov-Metzler inequalities.

Due to its nonconvex nature, a more conservative, but easier to solve asymptotic stability condition is proposed. It is expressed in terms of linear matrix inequalities (LMIs) plus a scalar variable, thus being solvable in polynomial time (see [3]) by the machinery available in the literature to date. It is important to mention that these stability conditions do not suffer a common drawback appearing, for example, in [14] where sliding modes are excluded and whose possible occurrence has to be a posteriori verified.

In this paper, the stability conditions expressed in terms of the Lyapunov-Metzler inequalities are developed further to cope with the determination of lower and upper bounds on the cost associated with the optimal switching control strategy. It is important to stress that a simple generalization of the Lyapunov-Metzler inequalities provides a solution to the Hamilton-Jacobi-Bellman inequality, an useful property for optimal cost lower bound calculation, see [18]. These problems are addressed in a general framework where a quadratic in the state cost is defined from a set of external impulse-type perturbations.

Throughout, simple numerical examples of third order are included for illustration purposes. A more realistic practical application of a switched linear system of fourth order is also considered. It consists of the design of a switching control strategy for semiactive suspensions in road vehicles, and is motivated by the papers [19] and [21], where two different algorithms have been devised. The method in the present paper outperforms these algorithms in all realistic simulations carried out.

The paper is organized as follows. In the next section, the problem to be solved is stated. The results on stability conditions and state feedback switching control of [10] and [11] for continuous-and discrete-time systems, respectively, are discussed. In the same section, lower and upper bounds on the optimal cost are provided. In Section III, the performance index used throughout the paper is determined. It consists of a guaranteed cost that bounds the effects caused by a series of external impulse perturbations. Section IV provides the solution to the output feedback switching control problem based on the design of a switched linear filter for continuous-and discretetime systems. Section V contains a practical application of the results obtained in the previous sections to semiactive suspensions that puts in evidence the main features of the theoretic results. Finally, Section VI concludes the paper. Appendixes I and II contain detailed proofs of two main theorems.

The notation used throughout is standard. Capital letters denote matrices and small letters denote vectors. For scalars, small Greek letters are used. For real matrices or vectors, ( ) indicates transpose. For square matrices, Tr(X) denotes the trace function of X being equal to the sum of its eigenvalues, and for the sake of easing the notation of partitioned symmetric matrices, the symbol (•) generically denotes each of its symmetric blocks. The set M denotes the set of all Metzler matrices, composed by square matrices Π ∈ R N ×N of fixed dimensions with nonnegative off-diagonal elements. Two subsets denoted as M c and M d are composed by Metzler matrices satisfying the normalization constraints N i=1 π ij = 0 and N i=1 π ij = 1 for all j = 1, . . . , N, respectively. Hence, each matrix in M c (M d ) has a null (unitary) Perron-Frobenius eigenvalue associated with a nonnegative eigenvector ν ≥ 0 ∈ R N . The unitary simplex defined for all vectors λ ∈ R N such that λ i ≥ 0 for all i = 1, . . . , N and N i=1 λ i = 1 is denoted by Λ. Given matrices U 1 , . . . , U N of compatible dimensions and λ ∈ Λ, the matrix U λ := N i=1 λ i U i denotes a matrix obtained by a convex combination. The n × n identity matrix is denoted as I n . Finally, δ(t) denotes the unitary impulse in both continuous-and discrete-time settings and the square norm of a trajectory s(t) defined for all t ≥ 0, denoted s

The existence of a solution for the Lyapunov-Metzler inequalities is discussed in [10] and [11] and relies on the existence of an asymptotically stable matrix A ∈ co{A 1 , . . . , A N }, which means that each matrix of the set A 1 , . . . , A N does not need to be asymptotically stable but they must admit an asymptotically stable convex combination; see also [9]. Moreover, in continuous time, closed-loop asymptotic stability is assured even if the system evolves on a sliding mode [10]. However, the numerical determination of a solution (if any) of the Lyapunov-Metzler inequalities with respect to the joint variables (Π, {P 1 , . . . , P N }) is not a simple task due to the nonconvex nature inherited by the products of variables. Hence, a simpler, although more conservative stability condition can be expressed by means of LMIs, thus being solvable by the available machinery plus a line search. The next corollary shows that working with a subclass of Metzler matrices, with the same diagonal elements, this goal is accomplished.
Corollary 1: The results of Theorem 1 remain valid whenever the following hold.
1) Continuous time-If there exist a set of positive definite matrices {P 1 , . . . , P N } and γ > 0 satisfying the modified Lyapunov-Metzler inequalities
div.formula: A i P i + P i A i + γ(P j -P i ) + Q i < 0(15)
div.p: for all j = i ∈ K × K. 2) Discrete time-If there exist a set of positive definite matrices {P 1 , . . . , P N } and 0 ≤ γ < 1 satisfying the modified Lyapunov-Metzler inequalities
div.formula: A i (γP i + (1 -γ)P j ) A i -P i + Q i < 0(16)
div.p: for all j = i ∈ K × K.

The basic theoretical features of Theorem 1 are still present in Corollary 1. Moreover, the extreme situations enable interesting interpretations. Indeed, for γ → 0, (15) reduces to the Lyapunov inequality that assures asymptotic stability for any open-loop control such that σ(t) = i ∈ K ∀t ≥ 0. On the other hand, for γ → +∞, the feasibility of (15) requires the existence of a common quadratic Lyapunov function for all matrices {A 1 , . . . , A N }. In other words, this set of matrices must be quadratically stable in which case, asymptotic stability is preserved for any open-loop control such that σ(t) ∈ K ∀t ≥ 0 with possibly arbitrary fast switching. Since v(x 0 ) := min i∈K x 0 P i x 0 depends on γ, a line search procedure may be used to get a more precise upper bound to the cost of the optimal policy. Similar interpretations can be done for discrete-time systems.

The numerical determination of the upper and lower bounds of the optimal switching control cost is involved and is costly. The main difficulty is concentrated on the determination of a Metzler matrix Π ∈ R N ×N that certainly requires further research efforts. For the moment, this difficulty is circumvented by replacing the search for a Metzler matrix by the determination of a scalar γ, as indicated in Corollary 1. This approach certainly introduces some conservatism on the calculations of the final bounds but it is numerically efficient. However, for Π ∈ R N ×N fixed, the associated lower and upper bounds follow from the solution of convex programming problems. Indeed, the minimization of the right-hand side of (28) written as

div.head: IV. OUTPUT FEEDBACK CONTROL
div.p: In this section, the main control problem reported in this paper is solved. It consists of the design of a stabilizing fullorder output feedback controller that minimizes the upper bound of the cost functional J(σ) introduced in the previous section. To this end, the model ( 1)-(3), given again for convenience, is considered

Corollary 3 (and for continuous-time systems Corollary 2 as well) puts in evidence a kind of separation property of output feedback control of switched linear systems. Indeed, a stabilizing output feedback control can be designed in two independent steps. First, assuming the state variable is available for feedback, any feasible solution of inequality (74) provides the control law σ(t) = u(x(t)) = arg min i∈K x(t) Z i x(t). Second, instead of x(t), this control law is applied to the state estimation x(t) provided by any stable observer-based switched filter satisfying inequality (75). Notice that this inequality requires more than simple asymptotic stability since all closed-loop observers have to share the same Lyapunov matrix X > 0. div.head: V. PRACTICAL APPLICATION
div.p: This section discusses a practical application of the output feedback switching control design presented before. The problem consists of designing a switching control strategy for comfort-oriented semiactive suspensions in road vehicles, and is motivated by the paper [21] where the so-called sky-hook (SH) approach is introduced and the recent paper [19], where a new strategy, henceforth referred to as acceleration-driven damper (ADD) strategy, is proposed that improves on SH in certain frequency ranges of the road profile disturbance. The model is given as

The coefficients β, k, and k t are the bandwidth of the active shock absorber, the stiffness of the suspension spring, and the stiffness of the tire, respectively. div.head: VI. CONCLUSION
div.p: In this paper, we have developed a new method for analysis and control design for continuous-and discrete-time switched linear systems. As important contributions of the paper, it is worth mentioning: 1) the development of a new stability condition based on the so-called Lyapunov-Metzler inequalities, and although more stringent, a simpler to solve version using LMIs plus line search, 2) the definition of a quadratic cost based on a series of exogenous impulse-like perturbations and optimality characterization by means of lower and upper bounds calculations, the first one provided by a feasible solution of the Hamilton-Jacobi-Bellman inequality and 3) the solution of the output feedback control problem based on the design of a switched linear filter or observer. The latter is possible when the associated performance cost is not taken into account. A kind of separation property between switched control design and switched filter design has been discussed.

However, in our opinion, some points deserve attention for further research. The first one is related to the development of an efficient numerical procedure to deal with Lyapunov-Metzler inequalities. In this framework, the fact that the nonconvexity is due to the product of scalars by symmetric positive definite matrices may be decisive. The second one, more appealing from the theoretical viewpoint, is on the development of a stability condition relaxing the assumption on the existence of a stable convex combination of the modes of the open-loop switched system.

J. C. Geromel is with the School of Electrical and Computer Engineering, M'02) was born in Milano, Italy, in 1955. He received the Doctor's degree (Laurea) in electronic engineering from the Politecnico di Milano, Milano, in 1978. From 1979 to 1981, he was involved with research on modeling and identification of environmental systems at the International Institute for Applied Systems Analysis (IIASA), Laxenburg, Austria, and at the Politecnico di Milano. From 1983 to 1987, he was a Research Fellow at the Centro di Teoria dei Sistemi, National Research Council (CNR), Milan.
